values:
Wow, it's been absolutely yonks since I last posted.  Chalk it up to Facebook.  So anyway, the year in review:

-First 3 months - finished teaching the little wet ones.  Cute, but after toilet training 20 children, I am so done.

-4-7th month (first term) - Solidified my reputation as a miracle worker.  The dance unit didn't know what hit them when I whipped them into shape.  Boss is now frothing at the mouth to put a competitive dance team out there and see what happens.  Who they gonna call...

-August - went home, lots of lunch dates out, lovely, yes.

-Sep-Dec - Very tired, Halloween was good, Christmas concert rocked out, guess what I did there?  Dancers in glow-in-the-dark skeleton suits worn backwards, dancers facing the back wall, having to do gymnastic flips and the like with the lights off (with blacklights tho) and the occasional strobe light.  Frankly, the rest of it sucked in comparison.  Christmas dinner, roast lamb by moi, with friends.  New Years will be the Brazilian Samba Contest (!) I hope.  It would be fun to shimmy on in and take the trophy off their hands.  Just my luck, there probably wont be a contest, but at least the guy I met last week will be there.  Why is it that Japanese men are scared of me?  Perhaps they read the memo I sent out.

-2008 - Term one will be developing dance music, to which I will then choreograph a mildly interesting routine.  NAH, kidding!  If I could come up with a dance which brought the crowd to their feet in about 2 hours while watching tv, imagine what I could do if I actually tried.  I will then apply to any midway-decent musician to come up with remixes of the techno persuasion.  Am thinking of releasing the music with a karaoke version (of course!  This IS Japan, after all) and a music video.


Oh, and I did the level 2 Japanese test.  Good old 2kyuu.  Hoping for a good result in February!  It wasn't so bad.  Quite reasonable, really.  Especially the listening section, which I could have napped through.

Well, I've been busy.  Went on a company-paid spa trip which included shopping at the Gotemba Outlet Community or whatever it was called, then I came home and wrote reports, and before all that we had the school Tanabata Festival and yes, the kids rocked.

By which I mean that for the last month I've been teaching Japanese festival dance, called Yosakoi, to the kids to gear up for the festival.  I even spent all of Golden Week sewing the costumes.  

They were good.  I heard that a few of the parents were so happy they were crying.  Given that it was only a week ago, I have spent the entire week receiving kudos far and wide.  Now that I've finished my reports, I am very relaxed.

Took the kiddies ice skating today.  It was actually a really good place and the staff there went out of their way to teach the beginners how to move about, and by the end of the class the phrase ZOOM, ZOOM, ZOOM came to mind.

Until one of the first graders fell and smacked her head, was sent to hospital where she was throwing up.  What do you think, should a 6 year old with concussion have been sent home within a few hours of the injury?

I think not.

Monday is a holiday here.  Then 4 more days of school, the last day of which will be spent cleaning, playing cricket, and swimming.  Unless this typhoon keeps the weather bad, in which case I guess we will be playing games, painting perhaps, and such.

On with the dance!  Let joy be unconfined...
I have internet.  Now, to youtube and selections of GNW.

So after having been on a wait-list since January, I got my super-fast internet connected yesterday!  Cheering noise!  Unfortunately those nitwits didn't leave me that little thing called a PASSWORD.  

After spending 20 minutes on hold, spoke to a lady who assured me that it was all in the info pack.  What info pack?  says I.  

I suppose on Monday or Tuesday, I will finally have internet access.

Allow me to introduce you to the world's greatest classroom pet:  Conifer!  Conifer is a long-haired white persian cat.  Meowsies!

Oh yes.  Conifer is also a toy with sensors in various places which, when activated, prompt different movements and sounds.  Purring and whatnot.  Plus after a lengthy name-choosing process with the children, other options being Kitty (ie 'Hello Kitty!'), Snowbell, and Zazu, Conifer was chosen as to its spiky and likeable nature.

So what the HELL is going on??  For the second day in a row, someone has made off with Conifer and hidden him somewhere.  It disappeared after I went home on Wednesday night, and I found it outside the toilets on a sink.  Kind of gross, yes?  Anyway, my class went on a picnic today, and it was there when we left at lunchtime.  After school we had a staff meeting, and when I went to the meeting, Conifer had gone again!  Given that there were no classes upstairs (where my classroom is) on Wednesday night, I thought it was one of the downstairs classes (the after-school ones, not the kindy kids).  But now its disappeared again, while a different group of kids were in the school. 


So who do you think did it?

Nap time.  Marvellous idea.  Interesting to note how many cultures have a post-lunch nap, Israel and Mexico for starters.  Too bad that Japan doesn't.  Maybe that nutter kid wouldn't have walked into the cop shop in Fukushima with a SEVERED HEAD.  Strange that in this country people willingly confess to crimes, and this kid felt the need to BYO his own evidence.

I hate Mondays.  Full teaching load, followed by an evening class which means I wont get home until 8:15.  I start at 8:00 so usually get there around 7:45.  12 and a half hours.  Gack.

So now it is Tuesday and I am trying like mad to study for Japanese class tonight.  Have finally finished that monster advanced-level textbook and am now starting on the test prep books.  

My teachers supply pack has still not arrived, so I don't even have the official tests for the kids.  So yes, I get to spend AGES making them up.

Need.  A.  Nap.

Five Tips For A Woman:

1.  It is important that a man helps you around the house and has a job.
2.  It is important that a man makes you laugh.
3.  It is important to find a man you can count on and doesn't lie to you.
4.  It is important that a man loves you and spoils you.
5.  It is important that these four men don't know each other.



Why, you ask?  For funsies!

So I was talking to a little boy I used to teach last year, and he's going back to Europe soon.  He's 4.  So he says:

'Miss Vicki, I'm going to be missing you soon because I'm going back to Belgium in two months.'

'That's right, in 8 weeks.'

'Not 8 weeks, 2 months.  At the end of Junie.'



Not June.  Junie.   Mew!  He's such a sweet little bunny, now that he's learned to stop punching the girls.  Am gonna CRY when he leaves.


On to other news.  In response to the parents of my class not being able to understand the work, as of yesterday we have a 'homework session' after school for 45 minutes.  Gah.  Hope it works.

So Golden Week is just a week off after 4 whole weeks of slogging it out.  I am making costumes for 33 hopefully grateful children.  I swear, if they dont learn their dance, I am putting the costumes away in a box and not bringing them out again until next year.

I booked my tickets home for the holidays.  Initially I was only going to have 4 weeks off, and then having to sit around at work for the last week of August even though there's no point.  But my boss seems to now have the point of view that since it is well-nigh impossible for the elementary teachers to take a day off, we can use our discretionary days to extend our holiday by a week.

SO.  I used my new JAL credit card (yippee!  mileage for shopping!) and booked the following:

Nagoya-Narita 1:55-3:00pm, Monday 23 July
Narita-Brisbane  9:30pm-7:05am Tuesday 24 July (NOTE parents, 24th!)

Brisbane-Narita 8:50am-4:45pm, Friday 31 August
Narita-Nagoya 6:30-7:45pm

Then 2 days until term 2 starts.  If I could just manage to get the parents to stop complaining about everything by then, that would be SWEET.

so this is the big decision i have to make.  seems they mucked up my contract and put 3 years instead of 2 like i said, but have since discovered that the money after 3 years is GOOD.  It is in fact VERY GOOD.

Have been entertaining visions of property ownership :)


vote early, vote often.

Aaaah the joys of a curriculum that I don't have time to teach.  But it is going quite well.

Yay!

Ahem, term begins again on Monday, so finally bit the planning bullet and did most of the gruntwork to get ready for the new year.  Spent a good portion of the school's money today on such frivolous items such as pencils, markers, and a jigsaw puzzle.

Great word, frivolous.  Also extraneous is a good word.  Likewise philanthropic.  When I was at uni I used to amuse myself during lectures (no, no point in actually listening to the lecturer) by keeping a list of quaint phrases that are more intellectual than the norm.  I always tried to include the word 'didactic', or even 'didacticism' for good measure.  How's this for fun: didactic antagonism.  Use it in a sentence, I dare you.  Comment with other delightful nuggets of wisdom, if you please.

So the concert last Saturday was beaut.  I took Sue (you've met her, mum) and it was the first night out without Noah since he was born 1+1/4 years ago.  We celebrated with meat pies afterward.  

The concert was humbly titled THE JAPAN DEBUT OF THE GENIUS CHASLIN, first name Frederic.  He really was good.  He was playing piano one-handed while looking at the orchestra and conducting with his spare hand.  Fun, yes.  And Puppy Dude over in the brass section did a good job too (I found his dog, remember?).  Here is what they played:

Claude Debussey - Prelude a l'apres-midi d'un faune
Maurice Ravel - Piano Concerto in G major (Allagramente, adagio assai, presto)
Hector Berlioz - Symphonie Fantastique - Episode de la vie d'un artiste, opus 14 (Reveries, un bal, scene aux champs, marche au supplice, songe d'une nuit du sabbat)

During intermission Chaslin came back out and played 'the death of love' (I'm working from the Japanese title here, ai no shin) from Tristan und Isolde.  All of these lovely things took about 2 hours, then 10 minutes of clapping.

Twas a good night.  Have spent the time since then cat-sitting, which HOPEFULLY will finish really soon as Whimsies is working my last nerve with constant whining.  Awww does Whimsie woo need cuddle?

Or kindergarten at the very least.  Said goodbye to the last little squishy person about an hour ago, and have begun trying to figure out the elementary program.

So.  No books for the kids yet, they haven't arrived.  Goody.  No supplies either, although I suppose I can remedy that by throwing money at the problem (let's give it up for well-heeled private schools!).

A new student joined my class last night, bringing me up to SEVEN.  Here's hoping I can survive the strain.  It's a surprisingly diverse group for such a small number, it should be interesting at the very least.  Oh yes, for those that missed the memo, am up for teaching the grade threes, currently the oldest and least populous class.

Am feeling... well, not good, as have only 1 week to prepare and have no energy whatsoever.

But hey, have two tickets to the Nagoya Philharmonic tomorrow, the result of my mad puppy finding skills.  The amazing person at the keyboard here runs not on caffeine, a good nights sleep, or even chocolate.  No indeed, she runs on props, so I'd like my fans around the world to begin chanting my name over and over.


That's enough.  A little goes a long way.

Am currently avoiding going home so that I don't have to do reports.

2 and a half weeks to go until I don't teach the small, cute, wet ones.  As of April I will be teaching the big, not-quite-so-cute, but-there-again-rarely-wet ones.  Yay!  So there will be no games of Surprise Hug coming my way, but I'm willing to bet hard cash that there wont be any nappies to change either.  So again I say, Yay!

I hates reportsies, yes precious.  It would be so much easier instead of actually writing paragraphs, just writing apt yet little understood phrases, such as:

-- Trojan Horse.  (= you think it's good, but then it explodes)
-- Hello Kitty. (= cute, can't talk)
-- Cracker! (= uses single vocabulary, not sentences.  Occasional hilarity ensues. 'Stop calling me a cracker!')

Had two Song Night concerts, one last Thursday for the Grade Twos (Kangaroos) and tonight was the Grade Ones (Koalas).  I love them both.  I just also love that the Koalas gave me a large Hello Kitty bag.  It is gorgeous.

Going home now.  Night Night!

So on Wednesday, I went out to Browns Plains to the Molescan clinic there - just a checkup, yeah?  Anyway, as we approached the Ipswich Motorway, we could see that the traffic was banked up pretty far, so we detoured around the back streets to get there.

Unfortunately the woman who was killed was someone who I remember from school - Rebekah Johnstone.  One for Richo - when our parents went to a wedding when we were really little, the Johnstones were the babysitters.  

RIP Rebekah.

For photos of my New Years, see Richoinca's blog.  Now!

www.livejournal.com/~richoinca

Ain't it great that Saddam danced the hemp fandango?  Hurrah! 

Q.  What does Saddam Hussein and Little Miss Muffet have in common?
A.  They both had Kurds in their way!  (curds/whey)

So I got back tonight from Newcastle, or Nova Castria as the bogans like to call it.  Nice little trip, plane tickets were a present from my brother HUGS to you, Richo!

A survey now, cut from an email to/from Ang:

1. What did you do in 2006 that you'd never done before?
Obsess over work, get threatened, feel threatened, and  ooooh win trophies for karate!

2. Did you keep your new year's resolutions, and will you make more for next year?
Didnt make any, waste of time as don't remember them.

3. Did anyone close to you give birth?
No

4. Did anyone close to you die?
No

5. What countries did you visit? 
Australia!!

6. What would you like to have in 2007 that you lacked in 2006?
More money.  Better musculature.

7. What date from 2006 will remain etched upon your memory?
dunno

8. What was your biggest achievement of the year? 
First karate trophy ever.  Nod from national team coach, saying I was "good".

9. What was your biggest failure?
Being friends with the bitch from work.

10. Did you suffer illness or injury?
Popped jaw in tournament (twice). not-formally-diagnosed anxiety disorder. Chicken pox.  4-week lung infection.

11. What was the best thing you bought?
Its a toss-up between my shiny gold converse and my Evangelion converse.

12. Whose behavior merited celebration? 
The guy that hung Saddam Hussein.

13. Whose behavior made you appalled and depressed?
Stupid people everywhere, in particular the ones I met.

14. Where did most of your money go?
Paying for japanese lessons and plane tickets and so on. 

15. What did you get really, really, really excited about?
Seeing BON JOVI!!!!!!

16. What song will always remind you of 2006?
Always, Bon Jovi.

17. Compared to this time last year, are you happier or sadder? 
Sadder.

17B. Thinner or fatter?
Fatter.

17C. Richer or poorer?
Same.

18. What do you wish you'd done more of?
Karate.

19. What do you wish you'd done less of? 
Caring about work.

20. How did you spend Christmas?
Arriving very very tired on Christmas Eve, sleeping through church, then visiting brother in Newcastle.

22. Did you fall in love in 2006? 
no

23. What was your favourite TV programme?
House

24. Do you hate anyone now that you didn't hate this time last year?
Yes 

25. What was the best book you read?
some romance novel.  Forget the title.

26. What was your greatest musical discovery?
THAT BON JOVI ROCKS!!!

27. What did you want and get?
nothing 

28. What did you want and not get?
Guess.

29. What was your favorite film of this year?
Harry Potter???

30. What did you do on your birthday?
Worked.

31. What one thing would have made your year immeasurably more satisfying?
Having Sonia and her abusive husband break their legs.  And have it
broadcast on Funniest Home Videos.

32. How would you describe your personal fashion concept in 2006? 
Anything to remind people that I am Karate Chick.  The Matrix outfit for halloween was a killer.

33. What kept you sane?
My friends.

34. Which celebrity/public figure did you fancy the most? 
too busy to care.

35. What political issue stirred you the most?
see above.

36. Who did you miss?
People in Australia.

37. Who was the best new person you met?
Probably the new grade 2 teacher at work.  Very nice person.

38. Tell us a valuable life lesson you learned in 2006.
"Some people are just bastards who aren't worth my time."

39. Quote a song lyric that sums up your year.
"Shot through the heart, and you're to blame, darlin' you give love a bad name."  Bon Jovi, who else?

40.  Hopes for 2007:
That it be a damn sight better than 2006.


May 2006 die an unhappy death, friendless and alone.  Maybe I could call the Iraqi hangman?

Oh yeah.  GOING HOME IN 2 DAYS!!!  Arriving in 3, but anyway.  I get 7 hours of waiting around in Incheon.  Or, from the glass-is-half-full mentality, I have 7 hours of SHOPPING to do!  Wonder if I can get a pedicure.  Ahh whatever.  I'll just read a book and people-watch (great hobby, particularly in a land that has stupid English words on Tshirts.  Wait, no, that's Japan.  Hey, a cross-cultural comparison!  'How many stupid Tshirts does Korea have in comparison to Japan?'  I could write a doctorate for UQ.)

Time to go home and pack.  Woo hoo!  company bonenkai (year-end party) tomorrow.  Might win prizes!

so my new apartment is down the road from the major park on this side of Nagoya.  Nicey, yes precious!  I moved on Saturday morning, and that evening I relaxed on my couch, watching Scrubs, and giggled to myself.  true, this place doesnt have aircon, but I will probably get one using my bonus in March.  Oh yeah, 3 more months until BONUS TIME!!!  I have *so* earned it.

La la.  My new place is a 3 bedroom place, one room of which is currently filled with boxes.  Need to buy:  aircon, more curtains, a light for the Japanese room.  

I CANT WAIT TO COME HOME!!!  Having been in Japan for almost two years, I feel like it is definitely my turn to go home and enjoy myself.  Am looking forward to the trip so much.  If I get sick, to give a random example THE RUDDY CHICKEN POX I will go nuts.

Aaah, food.  Am looking forward to visiting you down south, Richo!

SO.  In a rather interesting development, it looks like I am up for teaching the Grade 3 class next year.  I have to formally accept or decline still, and so this is the sort of thing I should discuss with my boss first... but hey!  The exciting thing is that it's on the cards, in the works, and up and running.

So, in a stick-my-tongue-out-at-a-cretain-person-who-shall-remain-nameless kind of way, I feel good knowing that my hard work has been noticed.  See!!  I knew that if I worked hard to the exclusion of all else, it would pay off.

Hmm.... grade 3s.......  someone remind me to buy a PE syllabus or plans or something when I get home for Christmas.  

Things to do/buy at home:
-food
-more food
-clothes
-more clothes
-Kanga cricket sets
-Wombat Stew big books, plus any 'Australia at Christmastime' type of books.  All this snow stuff from the northern hemispheric cultures is giving me hives.
-Decent PE curriculum
-DVDs.  Expensive perhaps, but still cheaper than Japan.  Probably.

any other ideas?  I wanted to go skydiving, but my brother didnt want to go.

So I'm just going to rave on, as I am tired and have 2 hours and 8 minutes left in which to do so.

I'll be moving house on the 16th of December, to a kind of place known as a 1970s 3DK, or in Oz-speak or 'English', as I like to call it, an old but big place.  Closer to work, cheaper and everything.  Only 8000 yen a month cheaper, but a saving is a saving nonetheless.  Plus, my current place is a 1DK, so 2 rooms less.

So, as my new apartment is so old it doesnt support cable, I will be losing my cable internet, tv, and phone as of midnight tonight.  So call or email my mobile phone until I get broadband or something in January.  

Also email me and I can send you my new home address.

Am filled with mixed thoughts about 2006.  Essentially I can't remember having had a worse year.  Everything is so much worse than how I thought it would work out.  I am SO looking forward to coming home for Christmas!  Only a few more weeks, then several days of shopping to look forward to.  And did I mention eating?  I am looking forward to several days of eating yummy Aussie food.  Email me also if you want to meet up at some point before I leave Brisbane - my flights get me in on the 24th of December and I leave on the 8th, just a day after mummy's birthday!!  Very exciting.  I cant wait to thaw out.

Mmmmmm very tired now.  tata until Christmas, most likely!

So today is National Exercise Day.  All the school kids are jogging through the streets blowing whistles so that everyone can run to the same pace.

I shall celebrate this momentous day in this nation's history by getting another coffee and watching dvds before going to Sue and Shinji's place for dinner.

So here it is.  I like my current school, but... Aaaaah dunno.  Money-wise, its about the same as Australian teachers wage.  The bonus payout is the big difference.  My trouble is that part of my wage is based on age, and I just dont like that.  I think that if we do the same work then we should get the same pay.  But hey, I have asked for the things I want, and lets just see what happens.  Quite frankly, it is expensive to live here and I don't know if I can afford everything.  And if I can't afford to live comfortably, then what's the point in being here?

Ahem.  So I've been teaching Nakagawa-san for a couple of months, and we tend to look at websites.  So, last Friday we put in a joint order to The Meat Guy (guess what he sells?), thus paying half the delivery cost each, and it ARRIVED TODAY!

Oh happy, happy day!  I ordered half a freezer-ful of meat pies and sausages.  And so now, in my tradition of eating something whilst typing, I bring you...


... ONLINE MEAT PIE.

Haven't eaten a meat pie in -ages-.  So I've got a beef pie with mashed potato and tomato sauce.  Have just cut a mouthful.  Here we go...

BRILLIANT!!  My eyes closed as I ate it.  This is so marvellous I can't think of the last time something tasted this good.  Actually, it was shabu shabu at Mitsuyo's.  When did I last feel this good?  Bon Jovi concert.  Excuse me whilst I imbibe further.  Is it possible to get meat pie IVs?  Or at least, a meat pie-dispensing hat.


Oh and in work news, my boss is away for a couple of days so shall be talking to him about stuff on Thursday.  Thank you mummy for the lovely encouraging email today :) (hugs for you!)

La La!  Must eat before it gets cold.

Tra la la!  Pay day is on Monday!  Do you think I can survive the weekend with only 900 yen?

I can't wait - first pay in 2 months.  I tried to create a poll that would have several options of how to celebrate said event, but the truth is, my pay is going towards:

a) paying 2 months of phone, cable, internet, etc.  Particularly phone.  Hi mum!
b) Japanese lessons have to be paid for.  Yay!  On Thursday we were talking Nagoya slang (dorrre!  roll the r) and so on.
c) going to the doctor (finally!) about my back.
d) buying meat from The Meat Guy.  If I could get off work before 5pm, I would traipse on over to the main store and save the delivery costs.  But hey, Mayumi and I put in a joint order, so we each pay half the delivery costs and she can take the delivery at her salon (the one next door to me :) and I pick up my share on the way home.  Hooray!  Meat pies and sausages for ME on Tuesday!!  Am looking forward to it, yes.  Considering that Tuesday is when I will be talking to my boss about recontracting, so I imagine that I will have some interesting news to relate on Tuesday.

I'm reaching out to the people in Kyushu, Hiroshima, Shikoku, and all areas effected by the typhoon.  Last count said 7 dead, and THOUSANDS evacuated.

For those who don't know, one of the worst-effected regions is where I used to live.  No worries, my friends are fine.  Talked to Hitomi in particular, she and her mum are fine, just scared about that train derailing and things like that.

Oh, and if anyone has been trying to call me, my phone has been broken for at least a week.  Sorry.  Email me or leave a comment and I'll get back to you.

Seems rather superfluous given the bad news, but my birthday present to myself arrived yesterday.  The Asuka and Rei interface hair clips.  They look awesome.

But anyway.  Sorry Sasebo.  Sasebo is near Nagasaki.  Some of the best times of my life happened in Sasebo.  Nagasaki too.  Considering all the bad stuff that happened there, the people are some of the most friendly and welcoming in the country.  Some really good people down there.

Unbelievable.  I was talking about Steve Irwin just last week!
Isn't it just so PRETTY? So far, the suggestions for a name are: Baiki Dick Turpin Lawnmower Whipper-Snipper, or Snip for short.

So I just picked up my new bike.  It's a Honda Dio, which has a higher body for us tallies to sit comfortably with.  It's black.  I wanted pink.  My helmet is silver.  Which would have looked better with a pink bike.  But anyway:

What shall I call it???  I call my bicycle 'Shuttle Hyperion' if you recall, so I cant call my Honda that.  RSVP with your ideas, the best of which will win a picture of me and my bike AND even a bottle of Thorpedo drink.
I have started putting photos up.  Click on the Scrapbook thingy.

I now have:

1) A Japanese driver's licence,
2) A re-entry permit for my trip home,
3) A really nice manicure (I swap English lessons at the salon next door for manicures)
4) Sore feet
5) Extra polish on my halo as I have been translating for Sonia and have found her a mechanic that takes Visa card so she can get her new (old) car checked.  It was so funny, the second we walked in he dived for the phone to try and find an interpreter, which we didn't even need.  But anyway, he passes the phone to me, and it turned out that his girlfriend is one of the ladies who works in the office at my Japanese language school that I go to twice a week for lessons.  Coincidences are great, this means he wont rip us off.


I am now looking at second-hand scooters.  I can get a nice, 2yr old Suzuki for 50,000 yen.  I might shop around, but this is at the shop right near my house so if there was a mechanical fault then I could go back in a convenient huff.  It's run by a little grandma-type character who said I could take it for a test drive.  Tomorrow's task, along with posting a -slightly- late birthday present to my brother.  Trust me Richo, you will like it.

And now, to go online and buy a Hello Kitty helmet.

So I was just watching 'Nyanko:  The Movie'.  Nyanko is a baby word for 'cat', translating more like, 'kitty!'  An hour of watching cats do cat-like things.

My favourite by far was Champon, a cat whose only activity is to lounge on the windowsill outside a Chinese restaurant in Yokohama.  Works like a charm, people lean over to play with the cat and suddenly decide to eat there.  People que up to take photos of the cat and decide that they might as well eat there.  It's a good system.

You know, I've tried to convince people at work that we need to have an AIS kitten running around the place.  The Orca class has a pet turtle, the Elementary kids have a guinea pig or some disgusting rodent, I WANT A CAT!  A cat that I can use as a neck-warmer in winter.  With a cat, one never needs toys to entertain the children.  And if the kids get rough, which happens so, so often, the kids will get a real-life lesson in that the cat will scratch them up.  A brilliant notion, no?

So what shall I call this cat?  Suggestions, please.  I am leaning towards:

- Hello
- Captain
- Bunny
- Rat
- Pookie
I just selected new mood icons.  And the joy continues to rise...

This is mostly for my parents who may wonder where I've been this week:  6 hours a day of karate, all this week.  Only one bad thing is that I wrenched my big toe and it is now purple.  But that's ok.  I like purple.

I CAN DO SPINNING KICKS!!!  I've never tried to do one before, so this is cool.  It's a move designed to knock someone off their horse, so you can imagine how useful this is in modern society.  Also, if you are Buffy The Vampire Slayer, it makes you look taller.  But I kind of feel that it's a move you need a soundtrack for, you know?  Everyone go listen to the song I am listening to now.  Is a good song for tobikaitenmawashigeri.

Tobi - jump
kaiten - revolution
mawashi geri - roundhouse kick

OK, this is my chance to rant.  Let me have a few opening remarks before rolling up my sleeves and commencing with the slaughter.

- I have a degree in teaching both English and Japanese and know precisely what I am talking about.
- I have worked all kinds of English classes, except for the upper highschool ones.
- I have connections everywhere.
- Oh, and have I mentioned that I have people queing up to get into my classes?  I wonder why.

SO.  I don't like stupid foreigners who come to Japan and act like the Japanese people, government, and culture owe them anything.  The above description is applied most often to JETs.  'Hey, did you see that pack of gaijin walking around, criticising loudly as if they owned the place?'  'Yep, they're the new JETs'.  'ooh.  Poor kids.'  Can you believe that JETs get more money than the rest of us, paid by taxpayers, and they can't even respect the country they are in?  Either find something you like, OR GO HOME!

You see, there are a few options for those who want to learn English.  For teenagers, they have weekly classes with the JETs, whose sole redeeming feature is that they are easy to push around.  Children, plus everybody else, can take after-school English classes from an assortment of companies and international schools.  Imagine a bag of liquorice allsorts.  Got it in your mind?  Well, I am the pink one.  My students can, funnily enough, *speak English*, which is more than I can say for the majority.  Some of mine do volunteer translating, and they're Year Two's!

Few JETs know what they are doing in the classroom.  Plus, few can speak Japanese.  It takes between 1 month and 1 year for JETs to learn how to plan and how to teach, and in the meantime, what have their students learned?  Substandard English lessons!

And it is unthinkable that this is the best they can come up with.

Oh, and it is crazy to hold up this program as a model to be followed.  Guess what?  I've heard that several cities are going to be scrapping the JET program and hiring proven individuals, teachers or otherwise.  Most excellent suggestion.

I once showed a video of a 4 year old from my school, who got up and sang the Aussie 12 Days of Christmas song, unaccompanied, at the school concert.  Thing is, she is one of many.

So here's a recipe for teaching English in Japan:  Hire teachers, or at least people who can teach without looking up girls' skirts (perverted gaijin everywhere!!).  Teach the kids something interesting, don't treat the kids like idiots cos they're not, and don't pay the teachers so much!!  They are supposed to be here to strengthen ties between countries, not cause resentment cos they teach approximately 4 lessons a day (what, 4 hours or so?) and get paid enough for two people.  If they really believe in all they stuff they spout at interviews and orientation, then make them take a pay cut to show that they are committed!  Or is committment what they are sadly lacking in?  Sign contracts that are longer than one year.  If this is their first trip to Japan and they arent sure if they will stay longer than a year, then dont sign them cos they will leave and then the kids get YET ANOTHER round of teachers who cant teach and take forever to find their feet.

I had 1 and a half hours to find my feet.

Winding down now.  Here's the thing:  at the award ceremony a couple of weeks back, all the teachers (mostly JETs or former JETs) were excellent.  They were an awesome bunch of people.  And here's the fun bit:  none of them matched the stereotype of JET as outlined above, ie they were not green, they loved Japan, and actually cared.  Why can't they get more like that?  Then I'd be content, nay THRILLED, to have JET as the forerunner of English instruction in this country.  As it is, 90% of the JETs I've met are not good enough.

My story begins yesterday, Friday 21st July 2006.  I spent three and a half hours at the hairdresser, then walked in the rain with a heavy nike bag of pink clothes and other essentials.  I got the shinkansen to Tokyo, which was late due to rain.  The shink, not Tokyo.

I had to hike for 600m (so the sign said, but bet it was further) up and down stairs just to change trains.  All the while lugging my beautiful nike bag around.  It was worth it tho, because en route I discovered a miracle:

For those of you not familiar with A) Japan, 2) Insanity or D) Merchandising Principles, let me give you a tutorial.  Whereupon dragging my heavily burdened self through multiple poorly-signed passageways, I discovered a new drink.  It is marketed as 'Low Calorie, Low GI, Sports Drink'.  Now say it with me, DUH.  It is essentially WATER.  Thus, is surely low GI.  The name and image of this nectar which surely makes you lose weight ('low GI!  low GI') IS:

... ... ... ... ... THORPEDO.  I double-taked then went and bought it.  Tastes like Aquarius with mild overtones of Pocari Sweat.  I have 3 spare bottles, which I shall auction off to the highest bidder.  Commence endless rounds of empty promises.

NEXT I arrived at my hotel, the OLYMPIC INN AZABU.  I thought it pretty funny to be walking into the lobby of a hotel called Olympic when I was drinking something with Ian Thorpe's picture on it.  Like I should get points for being clever??  It is a very nice place, small yet well appointed rooms.  Everything was good EXCEPT that I learned my lesson re cheap hotel razors.  I then fought to stop the blood flow before having to leave for the Embassy, which luckily was a mere 45-second walk around the corner from the OI.

The Ceremony:  Awards for outstanding excellence in the field of excellence.  Specifically, for Australian teachers living in Japan who can write a lesson plan worthy of remembrance.  There were two main prizes (1 for an Aussie, 1 for a Japanese) and 10 runners-up prizes (5 for Aussies, 5 for Japanese) of which I received one.  The main prize winners demonstrated their stuff.  The Japanese guy is a Year 4 teacher from Shizuoka.  He was awesome!!  I can see how I can actually use his stuff in my own classes.  The Aussie guy was nice, but... his stuff was very simple.  EG he tried to explain what an ALT and a JTE was.  If I taught like him, and stuck a lorikeet puppet on my hand to talk to my second graders, they would either A) be appalled beyond speech, or B) beat me with a cricket bat.  Anyway, I got some flags, puppets, and school uniforms.  As well as a very pretty certificate.  Talked to everyone I could, handed out business cards, hinted broadly at wonting to work there.  No luck.

Now, for my rant about how dumb the JET program is.  JETs have no idea what they are doing.  They don't know how to teach English because they AREN'T TEACHERS!  The people on stage were, for the most part, qualified teachers.  No wonder the kids in this country have no clue as to English--their teachers were, by and large, too lazy/stupid/arrogant to bother taking an ESL course or something before they came.  So these people force their pathetic attempts at teaching on students who need better instruction than what they are getting.  I respect the other winners of this contest for having written something useful and helpful.  I sneer openly at the idea that someone who's only claim to teaching is to be able to read a lesson plan that someone else wrote and mimic it like a monkey.  Grr it is infuriating to hear JETs go on about their 'lesson planning' and 'theories on teaching'.  They should use some of that obscenely high paypacket that they earn to buy themselves a clue.

So afterwards I went back to my hotel, and bought cold spaghetti from a vending machine near the elevator.  How to heat it up, you ask?  When there is no microwave in my room?  It's easy.  Pull a string on the side and little fairies inside light tiny little fires for 8 minutes.  So then I kicked back, listened to techno on sourround-sound, and ate Cookies n Cream in bed, reflecting contentedly that it is possible to have your cake and eat it too.  And I looked fabulous whilst doing it.
